identification.role: Centurion (youngest in cohort); tomb guard (crucifixion detail); third witness to resurrection alongside Longinus and Aquilus
identification.story_status: Active throughout Parts 1-3; significant character in Parts 4-9
identification.primary_narrative_function: Represents innocence encountering resurrection; embodies corruption of youth by impossible circumstances

physical_description.build: Average for Roman soldier (approximately 5'8"-5'10"); average, athletic; youthful physique still developing

distinctive_features.eyes: Clear, direct, intelligent; not yet cynical or guarded; post-resurrection: haunted eyes showing shock and trauma
distinctive_features.face: Open, friendly; readily smiles; less controlled than older soldiers; emotional states visible on face; youthful appearance
distinctive_features.bearing: Alert and upright but with youthful ease rather than veteran rigidity; stands with energy and readiness
distinctive_features.scars: Minimal; only training marks and minor frontier wounds; lack of scars marks him as inexperienced

physical_description.visual_signature: Youthful appearance; open expression; alert but easy bearing; apparent freshness despite uniform; haunted expression post-resurrection

primary_traits.description: Leads through respect rather than fear; troops respond to his genuine care; reputation for fair treatment
Genuine nature creates trust; people believe he's sincere; emotional state evident in voice
Instinctively recognizes right action; doesn't require philosophical frameworks; fair decisions
Youthful willingness to learn from experienced mentors; rapid assimilation of military knowledge
Fundamental innocence; believes it's possible to be good soldier AND good man; hasn't developed emotional calluses

strengths.shows_in: Soldiers' loyalty despite his youth; effective implementation of orders through willing compliance; reputation for fair treatment
Soldiers confiding in him; officers taking him seriously despite age; effectiveness in civilian interactions
Fair decisions; recognition of excessive brutality; compassion toward civilians

flaws_and_vulnerabilities.manifestation: Lacks experience needed to navigate complex moral situations; dependence on mentors for guidance; vulnerability to manipulation
Hasn't developed emotional calluses; visible distress at executions; more vulnerable to psychological damage
Experiences profound things but lacks framework to process them; confusion after resurrection; accumulating unprocessed trauma
Too dependent on external guidance; follows flawed guidance (accepting bribe); becomes complicit in others' compromises
Innocence is corrupted by forced exposure; unable to adapt quickly enough; trauma from rapid loss of worldview

core_motivations: Prove himself worthy of rank despite age
Maintain integrity while serving in difficult occupation
Learn from mentors Longinus and Aquilus
Navigate military service without losing honesty and fairness

relationships.dynamic: Hero worship → admiration with growing awareness of complexity → witness to miraculous transformation; Longinus's transformation becomes template for recognizing divine power
Aquilus's mentorship is most direct influence on Victor's decision to accept bribe; becomes fellow-conspirator in lie; bond deepens but also becomes tainted
Closest peer friendship; emotional support and understanding; shared lie bonds them; both complicit in same moral compromise

story_arc.opening_state: Hopeful young officer; eager to prove himself; believes integrity possible in military service; innocent
story_arc.transformation: Witnesses resurrection; terror and trauma; accepts bribe; participates in lie; innocence lost
story_arc.closing_state: Traumatized, morally compromised, spiritually confused; haunted by witnessed truth; burdened by lie

character.why_readers_care: Victor represents the innocent corrupted by impossible circumstances. His character demonstrates that witnessing resurrection doesn't automatically produce faith or clear answers—sometimes it produces crisis, confusion, and forced choices. Readers are drawn to his genuine goodness and youthful enthusiasm, even as they watch him face impossible moral choices. His tragedy—the loss of innocence through forced participation in brutality and supernatural events—becomes part of the larger story of how different people respond to divine truth. Through Victor, readers see how youth and inexperience make someone vulnerable to manipulation and corruption, while innocence is both asset and liability.
character_questions_for_readers: What happens when youth encounters brutality too early?
How do different people process supernatural events?
What is the cost of witnessing truth but remaining silent?
Can good people make compromises without losing their goodness?
